Amorim picked a rotational XI that was demonstrably not the strongest available to him, with two auxiliary centre backs in the back three and rookie Diego Leon in from the start.
After Mbeumo, it's understood that a goalkeeper and striker will be prioritised by Man United.
And according to Fabrizio Romano, the Reds have made initial contact with Royal Antwerp to request information about their conditions for a potential deal to sign Senne Lammens.
Sunday was a strange one with Viktor Gyokeres. Reports in Portugal claimed that United had made an approach for the striker which was higher than the fee Arsenal are said to be willing to pay.
However, that was then swiftly played down by the likes of Fabrizio Romano and Ben Jacobs. He is still expected to join Arsenal.
It's gone quiet on Antony's exit this summer in recent weeks but interest from Atletico Madrid could spark a move.

The i Paper have claimed that Atleti want to sign the Brazilian, who is available for around £30m. After signing Alex Baena, Matteo Ruggeri, Thiago Almada and Johnny Cardoso this summer, the La Liga side are plotting a move for Antony.
It's said that if Samuel Lino leaves the Metropolitano, Antony could replace him.
United have reached an agreement on personal terms with Valencia midfielder Javi Guerra, according to reports.
CalcioMercato journalist Daniele Longo claims that United have a verbal agreement with the player, but there still needs to be an agreement between the clubs.
United also face competition from other clubs in Spain and England.
Another 'talks' rumour here but one that Man United supporters should get excited about.
French journalist Sebastien Vidal has reported that United have opened talks with Xavi Simons' representatives, alongside Chelsea. RB Leipzig are said to want around £61m for the playmaker.
In midfield, Ben Jacobs reported over the weekend that Wilfred Ndidi remains on United's radar with talks being held recently for the Leicester City midfielder.
Bayer Leverkusen, Everton, Real Betis and Saudi clubs are all exploring the possibility of signing the Nigerian, who has a £9million release clause.
Alongside Benjamin Sesko, Randal Kolo Muani is on Man United's striker shortlist.

Footmercato has claimed that the 26-year-old is expected to leave PSG on a permanent basis following his loan with Juventus. Newcastle, who are set to miss out on Hugo Ekitike, are also in the running.

Benjamin Sesko has been earmarked as one of the strikers on Man United's radar this summer.
With Viktor Gyokeres set to join Arsenal, Victor Osimhen on the verge of returning to Galatasaray and Hugo Ekitike moving to Liverpool, United are short on options.
Sesko is being tracked and would reportedly be open to a move.
On Friday, Manchester United reached an agreement with Brentford to sign Bryan Mbeumo in a deal that could be worth up to £70million.

headline: 'Impossible' - David de Gea explains transfer decision following Manchester United exit
body: Former Manchester United goalkeeper David de Gea has admitted he rejected offers to return to England following his departure from Old Trafford in July 2023.
After 12 years at United, the Reds made the decision not to renew his contract following the conclusion of the 2022/23 campaign, despite originally planning to extend De Gea's stay.

De Gea made a cluster of errors towards the end of that campaign and United opted to release him. Despite being able to offer a wealth of experience, De Gea was without a club for more than a year, eventually being snapped up by Fiorentina in August 2024. He made 42 appearances in his first season in Italy, keeping 11 clean sheets.
The Spaniard has now revealed he had opportunities to return to England prior to moving to Fiorentina, but has admitted it would have been "impossible" for him to play anywhere but United.
"I turned down offers from England because after spending so many years at a club like United, you feel like you don't want to play for another club in England," De Gea told Cronache.

"I only wanted Manchester United, and while it's true that I received offers from England, I knew it would be impossible for me to play anywhere else. I've spent my whole life there; it's the club that shaped me and allowed me to have a wonderful career.
"I felt it was time to rest and come back even stronger."

De Gea, who could return to Old Trafford next month when United face Fiorentina in their final pre-season friendly, teamed up with goalkeeping coach Craig Ellison during his time out of the game and they soon clicked.
He added: "I lived between Madrid and Manchester. When I felt like I wanted to get back into coaching to get back into shape, I started looking for a goalkeeping coach to help me.

"They recommended Craig Ellison, and from the first training session, our relationship immediately took shape. There was a wonderful connection, he's a phenomenon both as a person and as a coach, I love him dearly.
"A friendship was born. He helped me during that break: I trained a lot and we spent a lot of time together. Lots of chats with an exceptional guy.

"During this year off, which was special for me given that I'd been playing at a high level for 15 years, I trained at the Spanish national team's federal training centre and on a fifth division pitch in England. I think this year off did me great mentally and physically."

headline: Mbeumo in, Sesko boost, three leave - Five transfers Man United can complete this week
body: Manchester United's pre-season will step up a gear this week when Ruben Amorim's men fly out to the United States to continue their preparations for the 2025/26 season.

The Reds returned to action over the weekend and played out a goalless draw in Stockholm against Leeds United. In the space of the next fortnight, United will play West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton in the Premier League Summer Series.

Amorim's focus will be on setting his squad up for the next season, but for many, including Jason Wilcox and Omar Berrada, the priority is on finalising certain deals and laying the groundwork for others.

Bryan Mbeumo is the priority and the move to finally bring the Brentford star to Old Trafford is expected to be completed in time for the 25-year-old to travel to Chicago on Tuesday. United reached an agreement on Friday to sign the forward in a deal worth up to £70million.

The deal will take United's spending past the £120m mark and with a new striker and goalkeeper remaining on their radar this summer, it's highly likely that players will have to be sold to raise funds.

After failing in their pursuits for Viktor Gyokeres, Victor Osimhen and Hugo Ekitike, United are back at square one in their hunt for a new centre-forward. It has left alternatives receiving mixed receptions with Nicolas Jackson, Ollie Watkins and Moise Kean all linked.

RB Leipzig's Benjamin Sesko is reportedly on their radar and after Arsenal opted to move for Gyokeres, Sesko remains available. It's unclear how quickly a deal could be done but Amorim will want to have a new striker in, should he get one, sooner rather than later.

Andre Onana's injury means Amorim is short in the goalkeeper department. It's been reported that Royal Antwerp's Senne Lammens is of interest with the Belgian side wanting just £17m, around the same that United are saving on Rashford's salary this season.

Player sales have always been an important part of United's transfer business. Marcus Rashford is in Spain to complete his loan move to Barcelona with an option to buy in the summer. It's understood that the La Liga champions are paying his full salary.

Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho, Tyrell Malacia and Antony, all not expected to be part of Amorim's squad for the tour, are expected to leave this summer. There has also been links with a return to Italy for Rasmus Hojlund with recent reports claiming United would now be open to loaning the Dane.

The current issue starring United in the face is that there doesn't appear to be any concrete interest for any of these five players. It means their uncertain future will drag on but, as witnessed with Rashford, a deal can come out of nowhere.

headline: Manchester United could solve transfer priority with player they wanted to sign three years ago
body: If you were to ask 100 Manchester United fans what they remember most vividly about the 2022 summer transfer window, the chances are you would get the same answer on repeat.
Former manager Erik ten Hag's first summer at Old Trafford will always be remembered by most for United's unsuccessful pursuit of Frenkie de Jong.
The Barcelona ace was identified as Ten Hag's top target to try and fix United's long-term midfield problem. They had worked together at Ajax prior to De Jong moving to Spain in 2019.

After more than three months of back and forth conversations between United and Barcelona, the Reds were eventually forced to move on. Casemiro arrived from Real Madrid just over a week after the infamous 4-0 battering at Brentford.
During that period United pressed ahead with other matters, recruiting Tyrell Malacia, Lisandro Martinez and Christian Eriksen. They also explored the prospect of trying to bring in a striker.
Unfortunately, they ended the window without bringing in a new forward, meaning Wout Weghorst arrived on loan from Burnley.

Nevertheless, United explored the option of signing then-Red Bull Salzburg striker Benjamin Sesko in July 2022. Former United football director John Murtough met Sesko's agent, Elvis Basanovic, to gauge the possibility of a transfer.

United's interest in Sesko never translated into a formal bid and it was announced in early-August the Slovenian international had agreed to join Salzburg's sister club, RB Leipzig, on a five-year deal, coming into effect from July 2023.
Sesko scored 18 goals in 41 games in his final season in Austria and officially joined Leipzig ahead of the start of the 2023/24 campaign.

The 22-year-old picked up where he left off, scoring 18 goals in his debut season at Leipzig. His 14 Bundesliga goals helped them finish fourth in the table and he also chipped in with two goals in the Champions League.

Sesko, who will be hoping to help Slovenia qualify for next year's World Cup, surpassed his tally of 18 goals in 2023/24 last term, scoring 21 times across all competitions. He scored 13 times in the Bundesliga and plundered four goals apiece in the Champions League and the DFB-Pokal.
After just two seasons in Germany, Sesko, who is under contract at the Red Bull Arena until 2029, has a respectable 39 goals in 87 matches. He has also registered eight assists.
In comparison to Viktor Gyokeres and Victor Osimhen, who have both been linked with United in recent weeks and months, Sesko's record is not as fruitful. However, he only turned 22 at the end of May.

His record of 68 goals in the last four seasons has elevated his profile. He is widely considered as one of the best up-and-coming strikers in Europe and he continues to be linked with some of Europe's elite clubs.

United have once again been linked with him over the last few days amid their need for a striker this summer. After missing out on Liam Delap last month, United have been forced to explore alternative avenues this summer.

The Reds are desperate to recruit an out-and-out centre-forward after finishing the last two Premier League campaigns with a negative goal difference. Matheus Cunha and the impending addition of Bryan Mbeumo will considerably strengthen United's attack, but they are still missing a key piece of the jigsaw.
Reports elsewhere have suggested Leipzig may entertain offers around the £70million mark for Sesko. That reported valuation will account for his record in Germany and his potential.

The Slovenian is on the cusp of breaking into the category of elite-level strikers. He has been bracketed alongside the likes of Hugo Ekitike, Osimhen and Gyokeres this summer, each of who are set to be on the move.

Truthfully, United would be taking less of a risk by signing a striker more established than Sesko. But after being prepared to take a punt on Delap after just one season as a Premier League regular, there would be logic in trying for Sesko.

headline: Marcus Rashford to follow 10 'strict rules' at Barcelona as Man United star nears loan exit
body: Manchester United's Marcus Rashford is nearing a loan move to Barcelona, where he will be expected to adhere to a set of stringent rules if he is to thrive under the management of Hansi Flick. Rashford has found himself on the periphery at Old Trafford and is looking to reignite his career at the Nou Camp.

The Spanish heavyweights have agreed terms for a loan deal with an option to make it permanent, and Rashford could prove to be a valuable asset for a team that flourished in Flick's debut season. Barcelona clinched a domestic treble last term, securing the La Liga title, the Copa del Rey and the Spanish Super Cup.

Barcelona's triumphant campaign reportedly followed the introduction of 10 strict rules by Flick, which every squad member is expected to abide by, as reported by Spanish outlet AS. The report suggests that Flick insists on players arriving for training at least 90 minutes early, often being the first one at the training ground himself.

A daily weigh-in is also said to be part of the routine to monitor the squad's fitness levels, while all players are required to eat meals prepared by club nutritionist Silvia Tremoleda at the Ciutat Esportiva canteen.
Additionally, players must participate in a warm-up session on match days, a practice that was reportedly abandoned under former manager Xavi following objections from the squad, reports the Mirror.

Flick also insists that his squad gather at the team hotel before every match, with the 60-year-old reportedly eager to 'oversee every aspect and prevent any unwelcome surprises'. He has additionally eliminated late-night flights following away fixtures to enhance player recuperation.

However, training under Flick proves extremely demanding, with Barcelona conducting lengthy and rigorous sessions that stretch to approximately 90 minutes. He has also abolished the penalty system that existed under Xavi, placing faith in his players to maintain their own standards.
It's reported that Flick generally limits his players to merely one rest day per week, with the manager expecting complete dedication from them.
He also seeks to establish a professional rapport with the team 'founded on mutual respect and dedication', maintaining there should be distinct boundaries between coach and player.

Flick has already expressed his admiration for Rashford, previously calling him a "fantastic player" when questioned about a potential transfer for the winger in May. "This is what we have talked about with the club," Flick said.
"In the last matches maybe we did not have a lot of options in that position... so we have to bring more options to the team and more quality.
"This is the job from Deco, is clear, and I will support him.
"I don't want to speak about players which are not in my team, but of course Luis Diaz and Marcus Rashford are fantastic players. I like them and we'll see what happens."

headline: Jadon Sancho two transfers away from completing Man United exit as £17m deadline clear
body: Jadon Sancho's time at Manchester United is expected to come to an end this summer with Juventus the current favourites to sign the winger. However, there are two major stumbling blocks.

Sancho has spent the last 18 months on loan at Borussia Dortmund and Chelsea after a public fallout with Erik ten Hag in September 2023. The move to Stamford Bridge did include an obligation to buy but failure to agree on a salary saw the permanent switch fall through.

The forward has made his intentions clear to leave Old Trafford this summer with Ruben Amorim not expected to offer him a lifeline this season. Juventus have been the leading horse in the race to sign the 25-year-old with Napoli, Aston Villa, Besiktas and Dortmund all holding an interest.

Juventus are making ground on signing Sancho with La Gazzetta dello Sport [via TuttoJuve] reporting that the Old Lady are looking to accelerate the move to get it over the link. TuttoSport have followed that by claiming an agreement in principle worth £15m has been agreed.

Now, TuttoSport have claimed that the Serie A side are waiting for the sales of Samuel Mbangula and Timothy Weah to raise the funds to sign Sancho. Both players are close to leaving the club for Werder Bremen and Marseille with Juventus receiving around £24.2m from the sales.

Director Damien Comolli is reportedly aiming to get Sancho through the door for July 24, when the Juve players return for pre-season. The possibility of a loan with an obligation to buy shouldn't be ruled out with Barcelona recently signing Marcus Rashford with a similar package.

The forward returned from his loan spell at Aston Villa with no route back to United's first team. Rashford will join the La Liga giants on loan with them having the option to make permanent next year.

headline: RAILSTON: Manchester United agree summer departure for goalkeeper
body: Manchester United goalkeeper Elyh Harrison is set to join Shrewsbury Town on a season-long loan.

Harrison spent the first half of last season on loan with Chester. The youngster started every league game for Chester and kept seven clean sheets in 18 starts before being recalled to Carrington in January.
United recalled Harrison to provide goalkeeping cover for the Under-21s and spend time with the first team. Ruben Amorim subsequently named Harrison in eight matchday squads.

The 19-year-old is one of the most highly rated goalkeeping prospects to come through the academy. Harrison's loan to Shrewsbury has been agreed for some time, but the move has been held up by an injury to Andre Onana, who is currently recovering from a hamstring injury.
United academy graduate Dean Henderson spent a season on loan with Shrewsbury in 2017/2018. Former England international Joe Hart also began his career with Shrewsbury.
There are high hopes for Harrison in the academy and United believe they have a goalkeeper who has the potential to break into the first team, which will eventually be his target.

headline: RAILSTON: I met Manchester United fans in Sweden - and they agree about Ruben Amorim
body: Everyone in Stockholm knew that Manchester United were in town over the weekend.
The receptionist at one hotel said they were fully booked because of the pre-season friendly against Leeds on Saturday afternoon, and accommodation prices had rocketed.

United shirts were dotted around Sweden's capital and the 50,000-capacity Strawberry Arena was sold out for the match. And while Leeds fans had a presence at the game, the majority of the crowd came to see United.
On the eve of the pre-season opener, local supporters congregated at O'Leary's - a sports bar in the centre of Stockholm - for an event organised by Manchester Supporters Club Scandinavia.

Members of different supporter branches across Scandinavia were present for a night of entertainment, which included a United quiz, music from Ryan Jarvis, a live podcast, and a question-and-answer session with former United players Jesper Blomqvist and Ronny Johnsen, who also signed autographs.
Many fans travelled from Norway and there was a healthy split between Swedish and Norwegian supporters in the bar, along with a handful of Mancunians.
United colours decorated each corner of the room and even the staff behind the bar wore United shirts. One employee wore a Jesse Lingard shirt and another had David Beckham's name on the back.
Blomqvist and Johnsen were generous with their time after the Q&A, taking photos with fans and taking time to chat.

The pair are idolised by fans in Scandinavia for what they achieved at Old Trafford. They were art of the treble-winning dressing room in '99 and never have to buy a beer when they are in Scandi territory.

"I first started supporting United after getting a Christmas gift from my grandparents," Sorkie said. "It was a Manchester United scarf and my brother got Derby County. And that's when we started looking up the games on Norwegian television on a Saturday, because it was only one game shown on the Saturday.

"Every time it was Manchester United, I was always watching that. Since then, it has been my team. I was not one of the founders of the supporters' club, but it started in 1981. I became a member in '83 and have been a member ever since."

Sorkie was proud to have Blomqvist and Johnsen involved. "It's really cool," he said. "The really fun thing is Jesper is Swedish, Ronny is Norwegian and there is a lot of Norwegian and Swedish people at this event, it's not just Swedish.
"I think we've been able to give people from both sides of the world, people from the Swedish and Norwegian community, a great experience, combining them tonight."

Sorkie continued: "It's really nice to have United back in Sweden. It shows there is a lot of people cheering for Manchester United in Sweden. We have sold over 6,000 tickets for the game tomorrow, and most people [fans at the game] will be supporting Manchester United.

"There are a lot of Leeds fans as well, but the majority will be Manchester United supporters. And that's why we say there is so much in Sweden for us to work with when it comes to building the Swedish Manchester United fan community."
The day after the event, United and Leeds played out a 0-0 draw and the game wasn't a great spectacle, but it was all about getting minutes into the players' legs ahead of the United States tour.
Over the next few weeks, Ruben Amorim will hope to lay the foundations for a successful season and Sorkie said he was firmly behind the 40-year-old ahead of his first full season in charge.
"I'm slightly optimistic because we have the chance to have a great pre-season," he said. "We can build the team around what Ruben Amorim is thinking and what he wants to get out of the team.
"Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo will change the dynamic in the team. I'm a little bit excited because there will be new players who are are equipped for that kind of system."
Sorkie continued: "It will be a lot better [the new season] because what was sad was Amorim came in during the middle of the season and he had to take all the players who weren't his choice.

"And now we're starting to see okay, with all the players that he inherited, does he actually want them with him? Which are going to fit in his system? And what does he need for the future to succeed?
"I think he has the knowledge and skills to change the team. He showed that at Sporting Lisbon. With the right players, with the right philosophy, we can achieve great stuff."

headline: LUCKHURST: 'What we need' - Amorim speaks out on Matheus Cunha and Diego Leon after Manchester United debuts
body: Manchester United head coach Ruben Amorim believes Matheus Cunha "showed what we need" in his first appearance for the club.
Cunha started in United's goalless draw with Leeds United in Stockholm, where the £62.5million signing from Wolves played 45 minutes.
The Brazilian was joined in the starting line-up by fellow arrival Diego Leon, who played on the left wing before he was replaced by Patrick Dorgu at half-time.

Cunha operated as one of the two No.10s, with Toby Collyer surprisingly selected in a more advanced role. Bruno Fernandes played in central midfield and is expected to remain there when the competitive campaign begins.
Fernandes was partnered by Casemiro, United's starting duo in the Europa League final defeat to Tottenham in May. Amorim conceded United have a "lack of pace" in midfield.
"We suffered a little bit when we tried to press high," Amorim told MUTV. "They kicked the ball with the second ball, they were dangerous in that moment.

"We have a lack of pace, especially in the middle of the park, and you can feel that's hard to bring the ball. But we create chances, I think Matheus Cunha showed what we need, that he's the player when he receives the ball between the lines, he can be really aggressive in the direction of the opponent.
"We have a lot to do but it was the first test against a Premier League team with two different teams, so it was a big test.

"We watched [Cunha] during last season in a different team, so we expect the same thing. You can see the connection between him and Bruno (Fernandes) is still not there but it's going to be a good connection because you can put a player like Kobbie (Mainoo) there, Mason Mount there. We have to increase our quality in the final third.

"We have to understand that the kid (Leon) came from Paraguay and it's his second week in Manchester United. He did really well, he's learning things, he's powerful. He's going to be a very good player."

United fly to Chicago on Tuesday for their three-game pre-season tour in the Premier League Summer Series. After the club's worst campaign in 51 years, Amorim is desperate to cultivate a harmonious environment as United prepare for their first fixture of the forthcoming season against Arsenal in four weeks.

"I felt the environment is really good," he added. "Sometimes we are going to struggle but we struggle together, and that is the beginning of everything. And then we have to put the quality, this club is not just about the effort, you have to have the quality you have to win games.

"We need to create that bond between everybody, not just them but the staff. All the changes are stopping, so we need to leave that as a group, we have a lot to improve, the speed of the game, all of the details. And we are going to improve."

headline: RAILSTON: United defender Patrick Dorgu reacts to competition with Diego Leon
body: Patrick Dorgu believes Manchester United's new signing Diego Leon is a "top player."
Leon made his debut for the club in the opening pre-season friendly against Leeds on Saturday.
United agreed a £3.3million fee, rising to £7m with add-ons, with Cerro Porteno to sign Leon and the 18-year-old will be assessed in pre-season before a decision is made on his next step.

Speaking before his arrival, Leon promised to "kill it" in pre-season, and he has impressed coaches in training at Carrington, which suggests he could have a role to play in Ruben Amorim's senior squad.
That means Dorgu could face competition from Leon for his starting role at left-wing, but the Denmark international praised his new teammate and believes he can help United this season.

"He's a top, top player," said Dorgu. "He's a good player, he's good for everyone. Everyone has competition in their positions. Every player has two or three players in their position. It's just going to help the team even more. Everyone's going to be on their toes, everyone's going to give 100 per cent to the team."
The left-back also discussed Matheus Cunha, adding: "He's a tough player, he did really well last season with Wolves. Hopefully he can bring all the good qualities to us.
"You can see today he's good carrying the ball, he's good in the small combination play. He can score goals and that's what we need. I think everyone is excited to see him play."
Dorgu's fellow countryman, Rasmus Hojlund, was included in the wholesale changes for the second half against Leeds.

Dorgu was asked whether Hojlund could get back to his best after taking a backwards step last season and responded: "I think most of the players had a step back last season. I think everyone wants to redeem themselves this season and I think Rasmus is the same."

He continued: "I have more to bring to the team, more to give. I'm just getting ready for the season, using all these pre-season games to get fit. Hopefully we'll see the best of me and the team in the first game."

headline: RAILSTON: Cunha offers glimpse into exciting future at Manchester United
body: Manchester United's season has begun and Ruben Amorim has a clean slate after a dismal 2024-25 campaign, although enthusiasm might have been tempered after the opening pre-season friendly against Leeds.
United have fanatical support in Scandinavia. The 50,000 Strawberry Arena sold out and looked similar to Old Trafford, with the red shirts heavily outnumbering white in the stands.

When the players emerged from the tunnel before the game, the loudest cheer was reserved for Matheus Cunha. United announced their £62.5m deal to sign Cunha on the opening day of the transfer window and the Brazilian started in the left-hand side.10 role, which feels tailor-made for him.

Amorim said he needed to see whether Cunha understood the position, but that he shouldn't need to think too much". And the first sign of teething problems came just a few minutes into the match when Toby Collyer had to urge Cunha to take up a more advanced role.

Collyer only broke into the first-team last season. He made his debut against Liverpool in September and lacks experience, but it's reassuring he possesses the confidence to instruct a senior teammate.
Cunha was in communication with a teammate himself, telling new signing Diego Leon to keep his width. Leon was essentially hugging the left touchline when United tried to build-up.
Leeds targeted Leon's side in the opening exchanges and the dynamic Wilfried Gnoto asked a few questions, but there was a lack of quality from both sides in important areas.

So much so that Amorim dished out tactical instructions to Bruno Fernandes, Amad and Cunha during a drinks interval. The pace had been mundane and the manager clearly wanted a little bit more from the players.

Casemiro looked off the pace and lazily fired a shot over the bar on the cusp of the break. The 33-year-old provided value in the Europa League last season but should not be starting for United in 2025/2026.

Noussair Mazraoui looked in good physical condition, which helped him to be United's best player in the first half. Cunha was the most exciting player in the first 45 minutes, although there was no competition for that prize.

Cunha did provide a glimpse into what he will bring to the table, though. He executed step-overs and won a foul. Then he was fouled again closer to Leeds' penalty area. He is certainly worth buying a ticket to watch and will provide entertainment this season, along with cutting edge in front of goal.
The forward scored 17 goals in a struggling Wolves side and the prospect of Cunha playing alongside Bryan Mbeumo, who will join United on their tour of the USA next week, has generated a buzz.
Opening pre-season friendlies can look similar to training drills and the players who started conducted a warm down on the pitch under the guidance of Emanuel Ferro when it was half-time.

Amorim replaced the entire XI at the break and gave an opportunity to Bendito Mantato who has impressed in training. The 17-year-old was deployed in the right side No.10 position, but has the qualities to excel at wing-back. The youngster was previously a left-back before being moved to the right wing by coaches.
Kobbie Mainoo was among those who came on for the second half and this season will be significant for the 20-year-old, who hasn't been able to nail down a regular starting place under Amorim.

Mainoo's momentum was disrupted by small injuries last term and there are doubts about which position he suits best. He played in the pivot in Stockholm and perhaps Amorim will settle on an answer this summer.
The academy graduate improved United and sprayed a handful of long-range passes, giving them an outlet from midfield, and Mainoo objectively looks more comfortable in those areas.

Rasmus Hojlund, who also played the second half, looked buoyant when he received warm applause from the Scandinavian fans before kick-off. Hojlund took huge steps backward last season but looks set to stay for the new campaign. He appreciated the support in Sweden and will be hungry to bounce back.
Tom Heaton made two brilliant saves to deny Leeds after the break. Heaton replaced Bayindir at the interval and should replace him as second-choice goalkeeper.

Rosenborg defeated United 1-0 in Norway for the opening pre-season friendly of last summer, and it's always impossible to gauge too much from the first friendly of pre-season. Some will joke the goalless draw against Leeds represents progress after the Rosenborg starter 12 months ago.
United will now fly back to Manchester and prepare for the USA tour. They travel to the States on Tuesday and will be primarily based in Chicago for the three-game schedule.
Amorim will hope his players are no longer rusty by then.

"You are competing against everyone else in the world because that is the reach of this football club.
"For me, it is about performing, working every day, taking the opportunity when it comes and hopefully keep showing the manager what I am capable of."

Heaton has not made a competitive appearance for United since February 2023, last featuring when the Reds beat Nottingham Forest 2-0 in the second leg of their Carabao Cup semi-final triumph at Old Trafford.

He added: "For me, the 90 minutes have been few and far between over the last 18 months, which is difficult. I know I am a bit older and further down my career than most people, but the flame of the fire doesn't stop burning.

"Every weekend, when you're trying to get in the team, it can be difficult, it is a real challenge. But I try and channel that energy every day by performing and when the opportunities come, making sure I take them.
"I repeat what I said before: I wouldn't have signed again for another year if I didn't think I could make an impact on the team.
"The manager is obviously here to pick the team and that is rightly so, but I will keep trying to do my bit."

headline: Arsenal face four-word question over Gyokeres as clown car Man Utd circle and Liverpool move quickly
body: Arsenal are mucking about over minor details of the most final-piece-in-the-puzzle signing imaginable as the clock ticks louder and louder.
Always a dangerous place to be in this game when you find yourself in broad agreement with Richard ‘Keysey’ Keys.

We are slightly in awe of the great man’s ability to take a perfectly reasonable and valid position and smash it to pieces with his trademark subtle deployment of absolute certainty and wild hyperbole, but however much we try, it’s still hard to take too much issue with the central thrust of his latest pronouncement to the masses.

If Arsenal don’t get this Gyokeres deal done they’ll regret it for ever. He’s top class. He’d be the difference between finishing 2nd again – or winning it. Isn’t that worth an extra £10m? What are they doing?

Textbook Keysey. We love the way he almost makes it sound like a threat with the sheer melodrama of ‘they’ll regret it for ever’. And the binary certainty of Arsenal’s only two possible outcomes – signing Gyokeres and winning the league or not signing Gyokeres and finishing second – is classic Keysey.

Even second doesn’t exactly look nailed on, does it? In the ‘regret it for ever’ scenario? Fantastic that nothing happening at Chelsea or Man City is allowed to enter the tunnel-vision certainty of Keysey Making A Point.
Anyway, having self-indulgently dispatched the wily fish hiding in that particular tweet barrel, let us remember and acknowledge that there really is a very solid point behind all that nonsense.
What, in fact, are Arsenal doing?

We like to think we’re ever so slightly more allowing of subtlety and nuance here, and will allow all manner of caveats about how we obviously know nothing of the behind-the-scenes difficulties that exist in the minutiae of any transfer.

But come on. This is just fannying for fannying’s sake now, surely? This is a transfer that Arsenal can obviously afford, for the most final-piece-in-the-puzzle signing imaginable at any Premier League club, a transfer for which the player himself is overwhelmingly keen and to which now the only major obstacles appear to be Arsenal themselves and clown-car banter club Man United still hanging around and honking their horn as the bumper falls off the car, which despite being small is able to seat an unimaginably large collection of unwanted yet seemingly unsellable bomb squad players.

Clearly, chucking unnecessary money at a transfer is not necessarily wise or the best course. But there also must come a time when stubbornly continuing to argue and haggle over the structure of a few million pounds in payments becomes self-defeating. Even if you get the deal at the price/structure/whatever you initially wanted, is it still the best deal if that player – one so obviously vital to Arsenal’s whole season plan – doesn’t arrive until deep into pre-season?
The campaign is now less than a month away. It is already reason enough to stop counting every penny in a transfer of this importance.

Unlike Keysey we cannot be certain that Gyokeres will prove to be the silver bullet Arsenal have been searching for. There are no certainties in the transfer game, and Gyokeres is undeniably costly for a player unproven in Europe’s top leagues.

But there are more reasons to suppose he is precisely what Arsenal require. Precisely what Arsenal have required for years now. And there can be no suggestion Arsenal haven’t done due diligence. Whatever else Arsenal’s pursuit of that long-awaited and obviously-needed striker could be accused of being, let nobody accuse them of being rushed or hasty.

Comparing one transfer to another is another risky business, because no two deals are the same, but it’s impossible not to notice the alacrity with which Liverpool have moved on to and apparently secured the signing of Hugo Ekitike from Eintracht Frankfurt in their own release-clause-adjacent striker pursuit.

Yes, it’s unfair to compare the two very different deals. And we’re not saying Arsenal should have gone for Ekitike either, especially with the Emirates being surely the most unforgiving place a Temu Thierry Henry could attempt to succeed.

But that doesn’t mean it isn’t adding to the frustration for Arsenal fans. They were already playing catch-up and watching Liverpool address what is for them a secondary issue while Arsenal are still doing some sums on their most important bit of business since signing Declan Rice cannot be helping.

headline: Man Utd: Rashford faces nervy wait as Barcelona work to register loan signing
body: Marcus Rashford has touched down in Barcelona to complete his loan move, but the biggest hurdle might still lie ahead, according to reports.
The Man Utd forward is expected to undergo a medical and train with his new team-mates this week, yet question marks remain over when, or if, Barcelona will be able to register him.

Rashford’s move is the latest headline in a chaotic summer at Camp Nou. The deal itself is understood to be a 12-month loan with a £26 million option to buy, with Barcelona covering 100 per cent of his reduced wage.

Rashford is desperate to revive his career after falling out of favour at Old Trafford. The academy graduate spent the second half of last season on loan at Aston Villa, where he managed four goals and six assists in 17 appearances.
Despite glimpses of form, Utd made it clear he was no longer part of Ruben Amorim’s plans.

In order to make the move possible, Rashford has agreed to a sizeable pay cut. The 27-year-old was earning over £300,000 a week at Old Trafford, but his salary at Barca will reportedly drop to around £8.6 million gross for the season.
He’s also waived certain image rights and performance-related extras to get the deal done.
Barcelona made Rashford their top target after missing out on Nico Williams, who himself nearly joined Barca before the complications began.
Williams ultimately signed a long-term extension with Athletic Club after it became clear Barcelona couldn’t guarantee his registration. That wasn’t a one-off.

Last season, the club were unable to register new arrivals Dani Olmo and Pau Victor before the start of the campaign. In Olmo’s case, his registration was initially approved, then later voided amid a financial compliance dispute. Rashford’s situation may now hinge on similar considerations.
However, La Liga president Javier Tebas has insisted Barcelona can make signings, so long as they work within the league’s financial rules.
“Barca will be able to sign players if they do things right,” said Tebas. “They know the limits, and it’s up to them to manage it.”
But Tebas said the same during the winter window, when a proposed January deal for Rashford was scrapped after Barca failed to offload Ansu Fati in time.
The club’s ongoing battle with player wages, salary limits and financial balancing acts means Rashford could now be forced to wait.
Barcelona are due to travel for their pre-season tour of Asia this week, and it’s possible the England international may not be registered before they depart.

Rashford could take the number 14 or 19 shirt at Camp Nou, both worn by club icons. Former teammate Paul Pogba reacted to the move by calling it “great for Barcelona,” adding that Utd were “losing a great player.”

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Man City to spend £180m-plus to re-sign England stars?
body: This way for some glorious bullsh*t about Manchester City and Cole Palmer. There could be something in the James Trafford links, though…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) 🆕 Cole Palmer – Chelsea to Manchester City
Apparently, Pep Guardiola is ‘determined’ to bring back Palmer at all costs and a £147million offer is on its way to Chelsea. It’s not, though, is it? Next.
19) Rasmus Hojlund – Manchester United to AC Milan
Milan are looking into the feasibility of signing Hojlund as they search for a striker and the player’s agent is pushing him back towards Serie A. But United paid Atalanta £72million two years ago and the Rossoneri would struggle to give the Red Devils half of their money back. So this feels like a non-starter.

18) 🔼 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting Lisbon to Manchester United
Back here again, are we? Apparently so, according to reports in Portugal. The stories go that United are close to an agreement with Sporting, which sounds very convenient for the Portuguese club, but its is a tactic that has already failed, so we cannot see why they would flog that particular dead horse if there was nothing in it. Gyokeres has made clear his intention to move to Arsenal, but he, like us, must be close to losing hope. If he did go to United now, the Arsenal meltdown would be spectacular.

17) 🆕 Conor Gallagher – Atletico Madrid to Tottenham 
This all sounds very tentative and driven by the players’ representatives seemingly exploring the midfielder’s options should he return to the Premier League amid expectations that he might not get the same playing time this season. Spurs are said to appreciate Gallagher and Newcastle are sniffing too. If anything happens here, it won’t be for a while yet.

16) Benjamin Sesko – RB Leipzig to Manchester United
Sesko is back in the 20 after losing out to Gyokeres in Arsenal audition but, apparently, United are ‘serious’ about signing the Slovenian. Maybe they are, and Christ knows they need a striker, but they will have to start selling sharpish if they are to afford what Leipzig are demanding.

15) Marc Guehi – Crystal Palace to Liverpool
With a year left on his contract and a renewal unlikely, Palace are willing to cash in on their captain – but Liverpool won’t pay the £50million or so the Eagles are demanding. Currently, we are at stalemate. Liverpool don’t seem twitchy yet, but they are keeping the lines of communication open.

14) Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Chelsea
Chelsea are selling one winger for £52million and reports suggest they could sign a replacement (do they really need one?) for £40million in the shape of Garnacho. The Blues were keen in January and, unbelievably, nothing between then and now has put them off the Argentinian, perhaps due to the discount on the hefty price they were quoted at the start of the year. Garnacho’s got to go somewhere.

13) 🔼 Alexander Isak – Newcastle to Liverpool
It seemed as though Liverpool were taking Newcastle seriously when they were told that Isak isn’t for sale. And the intent the Reds are showing around Ekitike instead doused our initial suspicion that Dicky Hughes wasn’t done with Isak. But it all seemed a bit weird on Saturday when Isak was sent home from Glasgow ‘due to the speculation around him’ and Eddie Howe sounded less convincing that the Swede would remain with Newcastle beyond the end of the window. Maybe this one isn’t done?

12) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Eze is keen on the prospect of moving to the Emirates and some reports suggest a deal is now down to the finer details of how the fee to activate his release clause is paid. Arsenal are a little tied up this week with Madueke and Gyokeres, but once those deals are done, we can expect some progress over Eze.

11) Yoanne Wissa – Brentford to Newcastle
Newcastle seem to have switched their sights from Ekitike to Wissa. But there could be more bad news for the Mags. Man Utd seem to have finally got their mitts on Bryan Mbeumo, which makes it less likely the Bees will entertain interest in Wissa too.

10) Luis Diaz – Liverpool to Bayern Munich
Bayern made their move for Diaz, who wants to make a move of his own. But Liverpool wouldn’t entertain the bid of £58.6million, with the Reds insisting they want to keep the Colombian, though £87million might twist their arm. There seems to be an openness from all sides to a deal, with Diaz keen to make it happen. Bayern will return with an improved offer but the player may have to do his bit too since Liverpool are insistent on doing it their way.

9) Jadon Sancho – Manchester United to Juventus
It seems Juve have finally agreed a deal with Porto for Francisco Conceicao but the sales of Samuel Mbangula and Timothy Weah will allow the Old Lady to sign Sancho too. Agreements are said to be in place with both United and Sancho, who should be thanking his lucky stars even if he’s halving his salary.

8) 🆕 James Trafford – Burnley to Manchester City
We all assumed Newcastle would pull their finger out after their initial bid of £27million inclusive of add-ons was rejected last month. Since then, though: nothing. Leaving City to swoop in for the England Under-21 keeper. Reports suggest City are trying to secure a discount on the £40million buy-back clause they hold for their ex-goalkeeper but with the increased noise around Ederson departing, it’s hard to envisage the Citizens allowing Newcastle back into the race.

7) Evan Ferguson – Brighton to Roma
After a loan spell at West Ham in which he did absolutely nothing, Ferguson is now close to joining Roma on loan, with some claiming the Italians will retain the option to buy. Sounds like a great opportunity for a striker once rated at £100million to kickstart his stalling career, assuming the two clubs can find an agreement over a fee should the loan become a permanent arrangement. Lord knows they’ve been discussing it for long enough.

5) 🔼 Marcus Rashford – Manchester United to Barcelona
This seems to be reaching its inevitable conclusion sooner than we thought. We knew Rashford would go on loan, probably to Barca, but we thoroughly expected United to drag it out. It’s almost to their credit that they haven’t, even if the fact they can’t sell Rashford for actual money is a mess largely of their own making. It seems the only sticking point is how much the buy option would be at the end of a season-long loan. Whatever it becomes, Barca probably can’t afford it. But that isn’t stopping them from covering his entire salary, for which United should be grateful.

4) 🔽 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting to Arsenal
Arsenal have missed Arteta’s deadline for Gyokeres to be on the flight to Singapore and some reports in Portugal suggest the deal could be jeopardy, with add-ons still to be negotiated and solidarity payments to be sorted. Gyokeres’ agents are working their nuts off but they don’t seem to be having much joy. To the contrary: the player’s father is said to have been ‘reduced to tears’ while Gyokeres himself is distancing himself from London. We genuinely thought this one was done, but it’s a saga that’s had more fake endings than Lord of the f*cking Rings. For all the good work Arsenal have done this summer, if they screw this up…

3) Hugo Ekitike – Eintracht Frankfurt to Liverpool
Newcastle saw the writing on the wall and backed away quietly, leaving Liverpool to argue the toss with Eintracht. Their first offer worth £70million was rejected and, to be fair to the Germans, the suggestion has always been that they want £85million. But with Fabrizio Romano now giving this one the ‘here we go’ treatment it appears only a matter of time before Ekitike joins Liverpool’s big list of summer signings. Certainly, personal terms should pose few problems given the player himself seems unsurprisingly enormously keen.

2) 🔼 Cristhian Mosquera – Valencia to Arsenal
This is done, apparently, with images leaked of the defender in his Arsenal training kit. The paperwork is still being ratified, but the delay between medical and confirmation is a pattern with Arsenal this summer.

1) 🔼 Bryan Mbeumo – Brentford to Manchester United
We have a deal! United have spent weeks haggling, only to pay more than Brentford’s initial asking price. But a medical is set to take place over the weekend before Mbeumo flies off to the United States with his new team-mates. Now for a striker. And some sales.

headline: ‘Unlucky for them’ – Pogba slams ‘crazy’ Man Utd transfer as he makes Amorim ‘sack’ claim
body: Paul Pogba insists that Man Utd “are losing a great player” in Marcus Rashford ahead of an imminent transfer to La Liga side Barcelona.
Pogba used to play with Rashford at Old Trafford for the Red Devils before the France international left Man Utd to return to Serie A side Juventus in 2022.
Rashford fell out with Ruben Amorim last season with the Man Utd boss claiming he’d rather play his goalkeeping coach than the England international.
The Man Utd forward was allowed to join Premier League rivals Aston Villa for the second half of the season and had a pretty successful loan spell at Villa Park.
And he has been allowed out on loan again, although there is still no official confirmation, after transfer expert Fabrizio Romano gave his ‘here we go’ to the transfer.

Romano wrote on X on Saturday: ‘BREAKING: Marcus Rashford to Barcelona, here we go! Verbal agreement in principle between all parties involved with Barça planning for medical tests next days. Loan deal with buy option, details being finalised today then Man Utd will authorize his travel to Spain.’
READ: The super secret transfer release clauses Forest and other clubs might sue us for revealing

That led to Man Utd legend Rio Ferdinand to give his reaction to Rashford’s departure on his YouTube channel over the weekend, he said: “There must have been so much going on behind the scenes that we’re just not aware of. And Marcus isn’t someone who really wants to talk and do interviews, so you have to respect that.

“But I’m sure it’ll come out in the wash at some point. Is it because of a lack of form? A lack of confidence? Mismanagement? Have the club failed him? Or is it down to him? Is there injuries we don’t know about? Has he lost that desire? That form is gone and he can’t rekindle it and can’t get it back?

“What are the issues that have led to a young kid that’s a graduate of the academy at Manchester United, which is famous for all of the great players that have come through there, that he says he wants to leave?”
And now Pogba insists that Man Utd will be the party losing out on the deal as Rashford is a “great player” who will have an impact at Barcelona this season.
Speaking to YouTuber IShowSpeed, Pogba said: “That’s crazy, but I’m happy or him because they took his number. Manchester United are losing a great player, unlucky for them.
“It’s great for Barcelona to be honest. I’m not even talking about United, because they’ve bought a few new players and the new manager wants to do his thing I guess.
“It’s not really his fault, if he doesn’t believe in someone. He needs to win. If he doesn’t win they’re going to sack him.”
Paris Saint-Germain forward Ousmane Dembele has been in amazing form over the past season and Pogba reckons his compatriot must win the Ballon d’Or this year or lose his chance forever.

Pogba added: “The Ballon d’Or? For me, Dembele will always be ahead of Yamal! I support Dembele 100%. He won the Champions League, he was very important this season. If he doesn’t win it this year, he’ll never get it. Hakimi and Vitinha were very good too. But Dembele is the favourite for the Ballon d’Or.”

headline: Man Utd urged to sign La Liga midfielder with ‘legs and energy’ while dropping player ‘at war with himself’
body: A former Man Utd midfielder has questioned whether the current goalkeeper has the presence needed to lead a side with serious ambitions, while also encouraging the signing of an energetic midfielder.
Gordon Strachan, who also won 50 caps for Scotland, believes Andre Onana is still “at war with himself” and that Man Utd’s midfield lacks the physical profile required at the top level.
“When I’ve been successful anywhere, I’ve had goalkeepers with personality and presence,” he told OLBG. “Whether it’s a physical presence, a personality presence, that is always needed in the team.
“When they walk down the tunnel and they see a goalie in front of them with a physical presence, a personality presence, then you think, thank goodness he’s there.
“The goalkeeper there now, I don’t think he’s got either of them. I don’t think he’s got a physical presence, and I don’t think he’s got this personality presence.
“He looks like he’s constantly at war with himself, worrying about making a mistake, and that he might have to go somewhere else to get that confidence back.”

Strachan compared the situation to when Peter Schmeichel joined the club. “When Peter Schmeichel went to United, it was one of the best things that ever happened to the club. There is a lot of talk about other players, but Schmeichel was huge.”
He also addressed the midfield, where the likes of Casemiro, Eriksen and Bruno Fernandes were regulars last season, and argued that Utd need more than just quality on the ball.
“They don’t need a bit more bite, they need legs—real legs, real closing down,” he said. Conor Gallagher is among the suitable midfielders linked in previous seasons.
“Can Conor Gallagher do that? Yes, he can, he’s definitely got legs, he’s a good teammate.”

Strachan admitted Gallagher may not offer the same creativity as others in the squad, saying, “Gallagher has the legs and energy—but not the Bruno flair,” but said that pairing energy with imagination could be the solution.
“Has he got enough imagination? I don’t know. But if you have people like that with legs in there and have imagination around them, then he’d be a good signing.
“A Christian Eriksen of 10 years ago could have done that in the game that is now as frantic as PSG are now playing with their level of fitness.

“So the days of the luxury player, if you want to be a top side, are gone. Conor Gallagher has definitely got the legs. He’s got the robustness. Has he got goals? Has he got that flair? These players are hard to come by.
“Would I take him compared to some of the players that have played over the last couple of years at Man Utd? Yes, I would.”

headline: Agent pushing Man Utd star towards £39m move as Red Devils have ‘replacement’ lined up
body: Rasmus Hojlund’s agent is pushing his client towards a return move to Serie A this summer as Man Utd set their price, according to reports.
The Red Devils have been on the lookout for a new striker this summer as Ruben Amorim wants a new goalscorer before the transfer window shuts.
Only four Premier League sides scored fewer goals than Man Utd last season with Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee taking a lot of criticism for their lack of contributions.
Hojlund and Zirkzee scored just seven Premier League goals between them last term and there have been rumours that one of them will be sold this summer.
Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano commented earlier this month that Hojlund “would love to stay” at Man Utd next season despite reported interest in him from Serie A.

Romano said: “Hojlund is not pushing to leave Man United. Højlund would love to stay at Man United, would love to continue at Man United, would love to do his best for Man United again in a new season.

“So, Hojlund would really hope and love to stay at Manchester United. The only possibility for Hojlund to go is if Manchester United decide to let him go, to sell him, to make profit with him, and all these kind of things.

“If Man United decide for him to go, Hojlund has to go. Otherwise, if it’s for Hojlund, I’m hearing that the player would be keen on staying at Manchester United and would love to stay at Manchester United.”

However, Caught Offside claim that Milan have ‘asked about signing’ the Denmark international, while another Serie A side, Roma, have ‘also showed interest’ but ‘can only offer a loan deal with a chance to buy later’.

Man Utd are ‘holding out for a fee of around €45 million and only want a full sale, not loans or swaps’ and it is understood that Hojlund’s ‘agent believes returning to Italy would be good for his career and is “talking to clubs” in Serie A’.

The Red Devils have already got a ‘replacement’ lined up if Hojlund does leave with Aston Villa striker Ollie Watkins their top target and the England star ‘could prove to be a major upgrade on the Denmark International’.
Former Man Utd midfielder Gordon Strachan said at the end of the season that it is time for Hojlund to move on for the good of his career.

Strachan said at the end of May: “There’s a point when you look at a player and think, ‘I really do feel sorry for you’, and that’s how I feel about Rasmus Hojlund at the moment. I went through something similar when I was at Aberdeen – for a year I was absolutely horrendous and it really gets to you, you almost lose your power to run and you feel debilitated.

“There are some clubs in the world like Manchester United where everything is too much for players, and it drains big signings rather than galvanising them. I think Hojlund is in that position right now.

“Do I think a loan move would help him? No – I think what’s best for him as a young man is moving somewhere else permanently. Everything seems to be too much for him and I think he’s in the mindset where he’s letting everyone down, which is a horrible place to be in.
“He definitely tries a lot, but is he good enough to be there? He hasn’t got long now to find out, because you can’t wait around for people at Manchester United.”

headline: Romano reveals Gyokeres to Man Utd truth amid claims INEOS are ‘most advanced’ for Arsenal target
body: Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano has revealed the truth over Viktor Gyokeres’ future after claims Man Utd are ahead of Arsenal for the signing.
The Red Devils are desperate to bring in a new striker as their next signing after they agreed a fee to bring Brentford forward Bryan Mbeumo on Friday.
Mbeumo will join Matheus Cunha, who arrived from Wolves in a £62.5m deal earlier in the summer, and Paraguayan youngster Diego Leon at Old Trafford as their first three signings.
And there have been rumours over the weekend that Man Utd are now seriously interested in hijacking Arsenal’s deal to sign Gyokeres from Sporting CP this summer.
Arsenal have so far struggled to get a deal over the line despite weeks of negotiations and a report on Sunday claimed that the Red Devils are now the ‘most advanced’ club in the race for Gyokeres.

But Romano now has an update on the Sweden international’s future and addresses the rumours about interest from Man Utd, he said on his YouTube channel: “I want to clarify something about Man Utd and Viktor Gyokeres.
READ: The super secret transfer release clauses Forest and other clubs might sue us for revealing
“Some very important outlets in Portugal are reporting that Man Utd have been working on a deal for Gyokeres in recent days.

“Earlier this week, I told you that Man Utd will sign an important striker this summer. Not that Cunha and Mbeumo are done, the focus for them is the striker and many agents in the market are aware about this.

“For example, someone internally at Eintracht Frankfurt expected Man Utd to try to enter the race for Ekitike when the deal collapsed with Newcastle. Man Utd were calling to be informed on the situation with Ekitike, but the player decided to go to Liverpool and there was no chance to enter into the deal.

“What about Gyokeres? I’m not aware of an official bid from Man Utd and I’m not aware of club-to-club talks. Despite intermediaries suggesting the opportunity for Man Utd to enter into the deal for Gyokeres, it’s very clear that Gyokeres wants to go to Arsenal. He is only convinced about the Arsenal project and he agreed personal terms with them two weeks ago.”
Man Utd have also been linked with a move for Chelsea striker Nicolas Jackson and Romano has touched on that as well as other transfer talking points at Old Trafford.

Romano added: “I told you earlier in the week that Nicolas Jackson is an option for Man Utd. At the moment, I’m not aware of talks ongoing with Chelsea, but Man Utd are informed about the situation of Jackson. They know that the player is not untouchable at Chelsea and so they are aware of the eventual conditions for his exit this summer.

“While at Chelsea there is still an appreciation for Alejandro Garnacho for example. So maybe that could be a scenario, but at the moment there is not a negotiation. At the moment there is no club-to-club talks about that.

“But, Man Utd are expected to go for a striker and one of the names being mentioned internally in the recent weeks is also Benjamin Sesko, another player who is well known at Manchester United. But before entering into concrete negotiations, we have to wait and see what’s going to happen internally at Man Utd in terms of outgoings.
“Marcus Rashford is going to Barcelona, but then there is Jadon Sancho, there is Antony and there is Alejandro Garnacho, so that’s going to be really important.”

headline: The super secret transfer release clauses Forest and other clubs might sue us for revealing
body: Arsenal and Aston Villa know they could cut out the negotiating middle man for many of their targets, who happen to come with tempting release clauses.
This is an inexhaustive list of players with release clauses which could actually viably be triggered from summer 2025 onwards. We are talking sub-£100m, not your daft £1bn La Liga jobs.

Diogo Costa
Manchester United have been linked with Portugal international keeper Costa before but Newcastle and Manchester City have both been mentioned as their staring contest with Burnley over James Trafford continues.
It doesn’t feel like Porto will hold out for the full £51.9m.

Aaron Ramsdale
After suffering his third Premier League relegation in six seasons, all at different clubs and with a spell at Arsenal in between, England international Ramsdale can thank the £25m clause he inserted into his contract for the fact he’ll probably be back in the top flight soon enough.
But Leeds, West Ham and a handful of others are yet to act on their interest, perhaps because of his wage demands and obvious curse.

Vanja Milinkovic-Savic
If Chelsea or Manchester City act on their apparent £16.7m interest in the Torino keeper and brother of Sergej then expect every other Ruben Amorim press conference to be spent explaining why no-one currently at Manchester United should really be blamed for releasing a teenager who couldn’t get a work permit in 2015.
He is 6ft 8ins so that’s something. But also it sounds like he’s off to Napoli.

Edmond Tapsoba
Newcastle are said to have offered £50m for Bayer Leverkusen defender Tapsoba; it is unknown whether or not they realise it might take as much as £80m.

Castello Lukeba
An eclectic cast of Liverpool, Spurs and Bayern Munich have been mentioned in discussions over Lukeba’s future, with a suggestion that Leipzig might not necessarily hold out for the French centre-half’s entire £77.8m release clause.

Ousmane Diomande
Crystal Palace have already identified their replacement for Marc Guehi, whether the captain leaves this summer or not. But they will not be paying £69.1m for the Sporting centre-half if they do sign him.

Miguel Gutierrez
A whole host of clubs like the look of Girona left-back Gutierrez at £30.2m – he was once described as a ‘priority signing’ for Liverpool and Manchester United are known to be lurking – but any hopeful negotiators will have to deal with about 427 clauses Real Madrid still hold over him.

Jhon Lucumi
Aston Villa and Bournemouth are sniffing around Bologna defender Lucumi, with Roma also contemplating a move for the 26-year-old who will only come as cheap as £23.9m until July 10.

Denzel Dumfries
Anyone wanting to sign a ludicrously effective Champions League semi-final wing-back can do so for as little as £21.6m until July 31.

Enzo Boyomo
Aston Villa and Crystal Palace are known admirers of Osasuna centre-half Boyomo, who has been crucial for a side he only joined a year ago.
Boyomo stayed at Real Valladolid for just one campaign too before moving to Pamplona; whoever triggers his £21m release clause might expect to keep him for a little longer.

Kevin Lomonaco
“I really like the Premier League. It’s what I watch the most. I like West Ham,” should raise an absurd number of red flags within the departments of any and all clubs charged with scrutinising the character and even sanity of 23-year-old Lomonaco.
The centre-half has attracted interest from the Hammers, Crystal Palace, Sevilla and Wolfsburg in his £16.7m release clause.

Jan Bednarek
Any club desperate to sign a centre-half with two recent relegations on his CV can do so for the cheap old price of £6m.

Eberechi Eze
Crystal Palace averted the potential crisis of having both Eze and Michael Olise’s release clauses triggered in the same summer but the fine print in the former’s deal has been reactivated in the summer. There is no shortage of potential suitors but still doubt that a £68m deal is worth it.

Morgan Gibbs-White
We are risking legal action from Evangelos Marinakis just by talking about a super secret £60m release clause Daniel Levy probably accidentally triggered when trying to low-ball Forest.

Wilfred Ndidi
There is unlikely to be a massive rush to bring in Ndidi after his second relegation in three year with Leicester, but the 28-year-old is on the radar of Crystal Palace, Everton and Fulham for £9m and it does feel as though a more stable environment would benefit him.

Samu Aghehowa
Another sign that Chelsea might have cracked something in the transfer code, Aghehowa was targeted for around £35m in what was basically a Conor Gallagher swap before the striker changed his surname, joined Porto and teased the sort of form which might attract £86.6m interest.

Hugo Ekitike
The fella is very much off to Liverpool after Newcastle’s game of transfer poker.

Nico Williams
The bad news for Arsenal is that the Athletic Bilbao winger has extended his contract to 2035. The good news is that he still has a release clause, and it’s worth £82-86m. You’re still thinking about the bad news, aren’t you?

Viktor Gyokeres
Another Arsenal target – to the chagrin of many supporters – but really any aspiring team in world football will have at least taken a look at Gyokeres before wincing ever so slightly at that £86m release clause.
Sporting might not hold out for that much but are among the best sellers across the globe and will back themselves to get the best possible deal.

Victor Osimhen
A record of 28 goals and five assists in 32 games for Galatasaray can be disregarded through the Turkish Super Lig rule of transfers but his age, affordability (£62.5m) relative to other strikers on the market and undoubted pedigree in Serie A cannot. Osimhen should be top of the Manchester United shopping list.

Benjamin Sesko
There is some debate as to the exact numbers which would compel Leipzig to countenance the sale of Sesko – £62m is the strongest recent claim – but less doubt about whether his record of 35 goals in 79 appearances in Germany is worth the risk on a 21-year-old.

Moise Kean
Everton might not get involved but after scoring 23 goals in 42 games this season, Kean could repay the faith shown in him by Fiorentina with another big move. For two weeks from the start of July the Manchester United target is available for as little as £45m.

Bilal El Khannouss
One of few players to emerge from Leicester’s latest relegation mess can be rescued from the King Power Stadium for as little as £22.5m.

Andoni Iraola
Bournemouth quietly fell off towards the end of the season to bring their dream of European qualification combined with FA Cup glory crashing back down to reality. headline: Rio Ferdinand ponders whether Man Utd have ‘failed’ Marcus Rashford amid exit
body: Rio Ferdinand has pondered whether Manchester United have “failed” Marcus Rashford as he looks to be on the way to a move to Barcelona.

Rashford was never in the good books of Ruben Amorim for long. The forward played just six times after the boss arrived at United last November, before he was quickly being left out of matchday squads.

After over a month of that, he was loaned out to Aston Villa, and though they had a £40million option to buy Rashford, his eyes have long seemed to have been wandering to Barca, even before he’d made the move to Villa Park.
Recently, it has been reported by Fabrizio Romano that Barca have an ‘agreement in principle’ over the signing of Rashford, which is believed to be for a season-long loan initially.
United legend Ferdinand, speaking on Rio Ferdinand Presents, has tried to come up with a reason for the club letting Rashford go after becoming a star out of their academy.
He said: “There must have been so much going on behind the scenes that we’re just not aware of.
“And Marcus isn’t someone who really wants to talk and do interviews, so you have to respect that.
“But I’m sure it’ll come out in the wash at some point. Is it because of a lack of form? A lack of confidence? Mismanagement? Have the club failed him?
“Or is it down to him? Is there injuries we don’t know about? Has he lost that desire? That form is gone and he can’t rekindle it and can’t get it back?

“What are the issues that have led to a young kid that’s a graduate of the academy at Manchester United, which is famous for all of the great players that have come through there, that he says he wants to leave?”

Indeed, there have been varying reports on the future of the United man in recent weeks and months. While Barca has seemed his priority, it was once suggested he’d be happy to bed back in at Old Trafford.
If that was the case, it does not seem United shared the sentiment. Then, not long back, it was suggested he was one of a few Red Devils who had asked to leave the club.
Rashford was joined on that list by Antony, Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho and Tyrell Malacia.
At Barca, surrounded by talent, Rashford might be able to hit the heights again, and that would certainly rub United’s faces in it after they allowed him to move on.

headline: Man Utd ‘talks’ for available £50m striker revealed as battle on for ‘priority target’
body: Manchester United have reportedly held ‘talks’ with a star striker who is available after ending a loan spell with a European giant, and is now a ‘priority target’ for the Red Devils.
United have been linked with some of Europe’s hottest strikers this summer. The likes of Viktor Gyokeres, Benjamin Sesko and Ollie Watkins have all been linked.
Though interest in Sesko has resurfaced of late, it’s believed that move will only be possible through player sales.

But there is now interest in Randal Kolo Muani, after Juventus declined the chance to sign him permanently following a 10-goal and three-assist loan spell there in the second half of last season, seemingly making him available for a move given Paris Saint-Germain don’t appear keen on him anymore.
The move would have been for around £50million, and given it hasn’t been taken, United have a chance to land their ‘priority target’, as he’s been described in a recent report.
It’s unclear if they’d be able to afford the £50million without player sales, though reports have suggested that Marcus Rashford and Jadon Sancho could both be moved on soon.
And United might have already made small progress on the signing of Kolo Muani.
It is reported by journalist Sacha Tavolieri that ‘recent talks took place’ with United over the transfer. It is not clear if any progress was made by the Premier League club in those talks.
Meanwhile, it’s believed that Aston Villa ‘could attack’ if Watkins is sold, while Newcastle – though focussed on Yoane Wissa – have also ‘made an approach’ for if Alexander Isak leaves.
That seems unlikely, though it’s been reported he is open to a Saudi Pro League transfer. In any case, the Magpies have been adamant that they won’t be selling Isak.
But there could be a battle on the cards for the services of Kolo Muani, with the Premier League sides going after him.

Each of the three interested sides could have issues financing a deal, though, with Villa and Newcastle regularly pushing up against Premier League financial rules, and United simply struggling to pay big sums at the moment.

After signing Mateus Cunha for north of £60million, and with Bryan Mbeumo coming through the door for around £70million, it seems very tough for Kolo Muani to be signed without a good amount of money first coming in.
With that said, the door could be opened for other clubs to pounce, but United’s upcoming sales could well help them.

headline: Man Utd ‘step up’ Belgian goalkeeper pursuit amid Andre Onana concerns
body: Manchester United are reportedly ‘ready to step up’ their interest in a Belgian goalkeeper amid concern over an injury to No.1 Andre Onana.

United have been on the hunt for a new goalkeeper this summer. Indeed, it’s been suggested they have lost patience with incumbent keeper Onana, given his propensity to be involved in errors leading to goals.

However, Onana doesn’t look likely to be going anywhere, but he has now been ruled out for the next six weeks. That saw Altay Bayindir play in a friendly against Leeds on Saturday, and means Onana will be out until the end of August.
United will likely have played at least their first two Premier League games by then.
As such, talkSPORT reports United are ‘ready to step up’ their interest in Royal Antwerp goalkeeper Senne Lammens, with the hunt for a new keeper required given Onana’s injury.
Lammens is said to be valued by his current club at around £17million.
Lammens is already aware of United interest from earlier in the summer, and feels he’s suited to the challenge.
“The first time I heard I thought, ‘Wow.’ Immediately a world [renowned] team that follows you. That is special.
“Of course, I was also spoken to about it a lot and when I made a save in training, it was United this, United that [from colleagues]… It’s only positive.

“Especially because it’s the best competition in the world and my profile, my stature and way of playing, is similar to English football. You have to physically hold your own there and that suits me.”

Whether Lammens would be able to displace Onana once and for all when both are fit remains to be seen, but that the incumbent is injured at the start of the season will mean for an interesting situation.

Indeed, if United are willing to change starters when Onana is fit, as has looked likely over the summer, then if Lammens performs well at the beginning of the campaign, he might well be able to keep the No.1 spot.

The Belgian, 23, kept 10 clean sheets in all competitions last season, which is one fewer than Onana, though Lammens has a far better save percentage from last season, and if he could continue that in the Premier League, he’d be a better asset than United’s current keeper.
Whether the move does go ahead remains to be seen, but United will begin to push harder soon.

headline: Man Utd now ‘most advanced’ in race for Gyokeres as INEOS offer ‘slightly higher’ fee than Arsenal
body: Manchester United are now incredibly ‘most advanced’ in the race to sign Viktor Gyokeres as INEOS have offered a ‘slightly higher’ fee than Arsenal for the Sporting striker.
Arsenal finally reached an agreement with Sporting Lisbon over a fee for the Sporting star last week, as confirmed by The Athletic’s David Ornstein.
Ornstein later revealed the ‘agreed’ fee between Arsenal and Sporting.

He wrote on X: ‘Sporting confirm a deal in principle is in place, with an agreement of a €63.5million fixed upfront fee plus €10m in add-ons, while the striker’s agent has waived his fee to help facilitate the deal.’
But the Gunners haven’t been given the green light to sign the striker as they have butted heads with Sporting over the structure of the deal, as explained by transfer expert Fabrizio Romano.
“On Viktor Gyokeres, I can tell you that the conversations are continuing in London. The agent is working on the deal,” Romano said.
“Arsenal remain confident but still have to negotiate add-ons. They want €3m in bonuses plus €7m more complicated. Sporting want €10m very easily. Any moment could be good for this deal.”
